ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [29th November, 1960], "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1961."

    Question again proposed.

2.33 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Mr Chan Sun Wing)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, on behalf of the electorate of Upper Serangoon constituency, I support the motion of the Minister for Finance which reads, "That the Assembly approves the financial policy of the Government for the year 1961."

Column: 81



    The long Budget Statement delivered by the Minister for Finance in this House on 29th November, 1960, gave a penetrating and objective analysis of the financial and economic situation confronting the self-governing State at present and in the years ahead. In the colonial era and the era of the Lim Yew Hock Government, there has never been such a Minister for Finance who could have given such a comprehensive and substantial analysis of the financial and economic situation confronting the people of Singapore. From the economic point of view, had the Minister for Finance given us in his Statement approximate figures of the profits derived locally by foreign enterprises in the past one year, and had he told us what percentage of their profits they were prepared to re-invest locally, then his speech would have been more complete, though perhaps we have no such need. But anyway, we must thank the Minister for Finance for his great effort in handling the finance and economy of Singapore in the past one year. He has pointed out to the people of Singapore the right way of overcoming the financial and economic difficulties through their own effort. The people can see, from his review of the conditions of economy and trade in our State this year, that in the 1½ years of office, the P.A.P. has not only brought about an unprecedented stable political situation but also a new situation of increased trade and expansion in production after a short period of economic standstill. Our Friends on the Opposition strongly put forth their propaganda that when the P.A.P. gained power, factories would be closed and trade would come to a standstill. This phenomenon has not come about at all. Of course, we have no reason at all to be too satisfied, because the increase in trade and the expansion in export still cannot raise the living standard of the workers and labourers. Our rapidly increasing population gives us many problems which are difficult to settle.

    However, I think it is necessary to emphasise the realistic policy adopted by the P.A.P. Government in dealing with

Column: 82

the economic problem. The P.A.P. believe in a society where there is no exploitation. However, we will not be so blind as to enforce radical socialistic and economic measures, because this will unnecessarily upset the social and economic order or structure. According to the Budget Statement of the Minister for Finance, our industrialisation programme will be carried mainly through the system of private and free enterprise. Thus honest capitalists need not worry about their capital investments not being protected by political measures.

    The working classes of Singapore, as a whole, have fully understood the situation in Singapore and have expressed their tolerance and wisdom in their struggle for better living conditions. During the past year, without their co-operation, the manufacturing industries and trade could not have expanded. Generally speaking, the working classes are not to be blamed for industrial unrest under the free enterprise system, except a few of them. In my opinion, so long as the capitalists and employers give their employees reasonable pay and reasonable working conditions, the workers of Singapore will shoulder their responsibilities to proceed with their production work for the sake of the State's prosperity.

    In the debates today and the coming days, our friends on the Opposition will certainly scratch their heads to think out some minor points in order to attack the Government, so as to pretend that they are the champions who fight for the welfare of the people. I maintain that they are all short-sighted people. No matter how or what they say, even when their lips become dry and their tongues get parched, they will not be able to show their talents in order to convince the people. Surely they will exaggerate and attack the Government, saying that it has given the people a burden to shoulder in respect of the tax proposals put forth by the Government. But, in fact, the Minister for Finance has already pointed out that in the eight new taxes of $10½ million, only $750,000 will be directly derived from bachelors whose income is less than $310 per month, or from those families whose

Column: 83

income is less than $500 per month. What is more important is that all the revenue from these new taxes will be completely spent on the social welfare of the people as well as on the economic development.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, while reviewing the financial conditions of our State, I think it is necessary to comment on several points. Firstly, at present, the two countries - the Federation of Malaya and Indonesia, which are inseparable as far as our State's economy is concerned - are pressing ahead along their own courses they have chosen. It is not an easy task to maintain and promote efficiency in the co-operative offices in these territories under these complex circumstances. The efforts put forth by our Minister for Finance in this respect deserve our appreciation. Secondly, up to the present moment, capitalist countries have not given us any positive and practical assistance. In the apportionment of finances for our future development plan, our Minister for Finance has said that he has no undue hope for foreign finances. This is very proper and correct. Thirdly, the expenditure of the various departments in 1960 is less than the estimated expenditure by $37 million. Naturally it is partly due to the savings in the administrative expenditure. On the other hand, it also shows that our State lacks highly skilled technical people. At present the Government has the responsibility of recruiting technically skilled people either from overseas or locally in order to fill these vacancies. By our long-term plan, those scholars at present studying abroad or in the local universities should try their best to equip themselves with knowledge and skill so that they may be able to shoulder the heavy task of improving the living of our people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the Government's financial policy.

2.48 p.m.

    Mr C. H. Koh (Joo Chiat): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government has presented us its Budget as a pattern of a fiscal policy; and it is a P.A.P. Government,

Column: 84

as the Hon. the Minister for Finance repeatedly rammed down our throats at every turn of his speech. Not the Singapore Government, but the P.A.P. Government, and the P.A.P. Government is allegedly a Socialist Government. And what have they produced, Mr Speaker, Sir? If this is a socialist Budget, all I can say is: I cannot see the sheep for the wolf's clothing. What I see is just the wolf - a Budget to tax the poor and some of the rich, a Budget that has no provision whatsoever for the unemployed who are tragically increasing in numbers, a Budget that has no provision whatsoever for the under-employed, a Budget that does not even take into consideration the retired worker who at the end of a long and useful life finds himself no longer able to work and, like a squashed orange, is thrown into the gutter. Not one word of old age pension, or unemployment insurance in this P.A.P. Budget. "Asians", says the Hon, the Finance Minister, "no longer accept poverty as the natural order of human society." That is in Hansard, Vol. 14, No. 1, col. 12, paragraph 2, Mr Speaker. Must Singapore accept it?

    The Hon. the Minister for Finance says in col. 40, paragraph 1:

    `...there is every hope that if we increase the inducements and facilities for private capital investment, we have every chance to achieve a sufficiently high rate of growth to provide work for our growing population.'

Let us examine that. Despite what he calls "improved conditions" in trade and industry and the impetus that he alleges the P.A.P. has given, the figures he indicates for the last 18 months show employment for only 1,049 workers in new small industries and the total anticipated employment, if all the `pie-in-the-sky' projects are achieved at a cost of over $100 million, is employment for 2,500 workers, and if we add to these projects still vaguer possibilities of all the enquiries and assume that each and every one of them eventuates, the total number of employment on these would be 2,000 - 1,049 already employed, and a probability that 2,500 may be employed in the years to come.

Column: 85



    How does the Minister equate these facts with his assertion that the rate of our industrial growth will meet the needs of our growing population?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I never said that!

    Mr Koh: `a sufficiently high rate of growth to provide work for our growing population.' I am not suggesting that industrialisation is not valuable. It is, Mr, Speaker, Sir. But it is important that the Government should recognise and that the people should know that the maximum possible industrialisation in the most favourable circumstances cannot employ more than 10 per cent of our unemployed. Let us not increase the tragedy of those who suffer idleness at present through no fault of their own, by pretending that they will get employment, and deluding them into hopes that can never be achieved. We ought at least to tell the truth to this tragic sector of our population even if we cannot help them.

    The Hon. the Minister for Finance has also spoken with roseate optimism about the future of our trade and commerce. There is not one single businessman I have spoken to who does not state categorically that our economy is sagging. Nothing dramatic - just sinking quietly like a ship in a calm sea; and yet it has been the unusual good fortune of this P.A.P. Government to have a tremendous boom in the Federation which would normally have meant a boom of considerable prosperity in Singapore, but which has only succeeded in cushioning the depression which has set in with the advent of the P.A.P. Government, a depression which progressively saps our economic structure. It is a pity there is no businessman in the P.A.P. to tell them the facts of life. Figures are helpful, but statements like "There is a solid and substantial revival of the economy this year" based on selected figures, are wholly misleading and unfair to the people, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Three!

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the Hon, the Minister for Finance wishes to elucidate, he might try; but he should not interject from his seat.

Column: 86



    Mr Koh: There is one small item I must touch upon and that is the Workers' Brigade.

    The Prime Minister: Works Brigade!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on a point of clarification.

    Mr Speaker: If the Member will give way.

    Mr Koh: Very well.

    The Prime Minister: I think it would help considerably all round in our appreciation of what the Member for Joo Chiat hopes to contribute to the economic thinking of this country, if we refer to things by the names they are referred to in the Budget and in the newspapers.

    Mr Speaker: I did not quite catch the point raised.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, in the Estimates, in the Budget speech and in the newspapers, there are references made to the Works Brigade. If we are to coin new nomenclatures for the same or different things, then perhaps we might get ourselves lost well before the Member for Joo Chiat is finished in the next few minutes.

    Mr Koh: Mr Speaker, I do not wish to go down to the personal level; but names, names and names. Is that all what the Prime Minister is capable of saying? What does it matter whether it is the Works Brigade or the Workers' Brigade? What is in a name? It is really the merits that count. The P.A.P. Government has changed so many names in this country that we are apt to get a headache. I feel like calling some names too, but I think I had better not digress.

    However, it seems to me, Sir, that the establishment of the Works Brigade and the work it is doing negates the basic principles of trade unionism. The Works Brigade is cheap labour at below the market rates for Government projects. In the long run, this is an unhealthy approach to the needs of the country and one to which the trade unions of the country should awaken.

Column: 87



    Dr Goh Keng Swee: On a point of information.

    Mr Koh: No, Sir, I do not wish any more interruptions. It is the duty of Government, as an employer, not to undermine the trade union movement by a reserve of cheap labour, but to pay in full for the services it receives.

    One other matter on which I must touch is the question of the treatment of the civil servants, and the tender generosity of the Government in stating that they are willing to have negotiations for partial restoration of variable allowances; or is "restitution" the word used instead of "restoration"? I cannot remember. It is a tragic farce that Government should offer to give the civil servants a very small percentage of what is their rightful due with one hand, and then take it away in their increased taxation with the other. And what is more deplorable, Mr Speaker, Sir, is that there is in existence a freely negotiated agreement between the Government and the Civil Service for arbitration on pay and conditions of service, and the civil servants have pleaded earnestly for an Arbitration Tribunal to be appointed to consider their legitimate complaints about the manner of the reduction of variable allowances and about the need for such reduction in the light of the Surplus Budgets of the P.A.P. Government. Despite the formal agreement freely negotiated, the Government refuse to arbitrate because they state that this is a matter of policy. I am reminded of the story of the Chinese cook in a Muslim household, who was in no uncertain terms told that pork should never be brought to the house. One day he was found eating pork. When asked for an explanation, he said, "This no pork; this fish. I put pork in water. I say, `Pork, pork, you no pork. You fish." And so we have government as the major employer encouraging-

    The Minister for Labour and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): On a point of clarification?

    Mr Speaker: On a point of clarification.

Column: 88



    Mr Byrne: I am very confused, Sir. [Laughter]

    Mr Speaker: Order. Please continue.

    Mr Koh: And so we have Government as the major employer encouraging employers, by their own conduct, to deny solemn agreements freely entered into. [Laughter.] Laughter or no laughter, that is what is happening. In the case of the Civil Service the sum involved is not very great, but the number of people involved are a large number of loyal servants of the country. Not only they, but their dependants, and the trade which their expenditure brings. It is a shameful thing that Singapore should dishonour its obligations to its civil servants and pretend generosity in restoring them just enough to pay their own income tax increases.

    On Indonesia, Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. the Finance Minister's remarks about our trade with Indonesia highlight what has been known by most of us, and that is that the Prime Minister's mission to Indonesia has been a complete failure despite the pink smoke screen emanating from the Ministry of Culture.

    An hon. Member: Why pink?

    Mr Koh: This failure emphasises the need for a well-trained experienced Singapore Trade Commission permanently established in Djakarta. I therefore welcome the statement of the Hon. the Minister for Finance that a Trade and Cultural Commission will be established in Djakarta. Not only in Djakarta, Mr Speaker, Sir, but also I think in other neighbouring territories, and as far as China, there is an imperative need for us to establish permanent Trade Commissions. One final matter, Mr Speaker, Sir. The newspapers have given the impression that the Government has promised to stand-still taxation for three years. My understanding of the Finance Minister's speech is that that is only in respect of Property Tax.

    An hon. Member: You read the wrong newspaper!

    Mr Koh: There is no promise at all in respect of income tax or any of the other taxes. Will the Hon. the Minister for Finance clarify?

Column: 89



    Now, Sir, the business tax. I would like most emphatically and most forcibly to draw the attention of the Hon, the Minister for Finance to this point, and that is, despite what he might say about the economic conditions of this country, those of us who mix with business people in this country know that many a business is being run at a loss. To put a business tax of $1,000 on a big limited company would not hurt that company. But unfortunately, a tax of $750 on the smaller companies will hurt them tremendously and will cause them great hardship, because most of them are now being run at a toss. I hope the Finance Minister will not laugh that one off.

    In conclusion, let me say that this Budget is not a Socialist Budget, nor is it a Budget that adequately meets the realities of today and the economic problems of tomorrow of Singapore.

    I shall vote against the motion.

3.06 p.m.

    Dato Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat (Geylang Serai): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has placed before us facts and figures to prove his contention that everything is plain sailing and that there is nothing to worry about. Yet, Sir, by his own calculation, he says that about $30 million will not be spent from this year's Budget. This in effect means, again in the Minister's own words, that `there will be less rural roads and bridges this year, less doctors and specialists, less maintenance work by P.W.D., fewer scholarships, fewer fellowships, fewer police constables, fewer teachers and fewer technicians.' The people of Singapore, Sir, will have everything less in 1960. And yet the Minister for Finance tells us in effect that we have never had it so good. I say, Sir, that we have never had it so bad, what with the increasing number of unemployed and more to feed on less income per head.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Stop producing!

    Dato Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, admittedly there has been an increase in the flow of trade, but this

Column: 90

seeming prosperity is not the result of Government's initiative but an act of God.

    The price of rubber, Sir, has been good, and the increased output of this commodity in the Federation of Malaya and its export through the port of Singapore has, again as the Minister has pointed out, directly benefited the State. In other words, Sir, we - I mean the people of Singapore - live on the exertions and goodwill of our neighbours. This state of affairs cannot continue, and will not continue for long. This House is no doubt aware that the Federation Government is making every effort to expand the port facilities at Port Swettenham and Sebarang Prai; and then there is even talk of exploiting the harbour at Port Dickson, not to mention the proposed international airport at Kuala Lumpur. Nothing, Sir, can induce the Federation Government to stop proceeding with these schemes. At the same time, they are in the process of establishing a rubber and stock exchange market in the Federal capital.

    All this hive of activity in the Federation points to one fact. Very soon, and probably during the life-time of this Government, a large portion of our entrepot trade will cease to exist.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the other support of our economic life, Indonesia, has already shown a tendency to crack. The Minister for Finance, in his Budget speech, and here, Sir, I quote from Hansard, Vol. 14, No. I col. 14, which says:

    `Many of the problems arising in our trade with Indonesia are long standing and difficult. While we are a free trade economy with controls reduced to the barest minimum, the Indonesians prefer a policy of "guided economy". This, in effect, means the imposition of controls over all major aspects of trade and production. What we have to do is to meet the legitimate requirements of Indonesia's guided economy in such a way as not to destroy our entrepot trade.'

That was what the Minister for Finance said in his Budget speech. Whilst on the one hand we must give credit to the Prime Minister for his efforts to improve friendly, relations with Indonesia - and I admit he has to some extent

Column: 91

been successful - the economic relations between the two countries have not shown any visible signs of improvement. The key to our economic survival is our entrepot trade. This is not the first time that the Government of Singapore has sent missions across the Java sea. During the David Marshall regime, a similar Ministerial mission spent some time in Djakarta followed later by two fact-finding missions from Indonesia. Though there was some slight improvement in relations between the two countries, nothing came out of the whole affair. In fact, Sir, at that time, there was no guided democracy and no guided economy to contend with. As I see it. Sir, the basic fact then was, as it is now, the desire of the Indonesian Government to eliminate what it calls the smuggling trade. Singapore, being a free port, places no insurmountable restrictions on its imports, and hence does not in the nature of things control the commodities that enter its waters nor enquire into the sources of the imported goods. In other words, Sir, not all goods imported into the State of Singapore from Indonesia have gone through the proper controlling authorities at the port of loading. Hence what we call free trade, the Indonesians call smuggling. What the Indonesian Government wanted Singapore to do was to be its policeman. And this situation Singapore was unwilling to accept.

    Not only would it create a bad precedent, Sir, but it would also upset the whole structure of our free port status. The position today is still the same, guided economy or not. To the Indonesians, it is not only a matter of national pride but also a matter of economic survival. If they can manage to seal this leak and a few others in Borneo and Sarawak, they feel they can certainly overcome the periodic economic stresses that seem to confront them from time to time. My sympathies, Sir, are with them.

Column: 92



    Mr Speaker, Sir, from this, it could be seen that the economic survival of Singapore depends largely on the goodwill and tolerance of our two great neighbours, Indonesia and the Federation of Malaya. How long we can depend on this goodwill, again only the gods can tell. It is therefore the duty of the Government of Singapore, whether it be the P.A.P. Government or any other, to provide alternative sources of livelihood for its people before disaster overtakes them.

    The Government's Five-Year Plan is an admirable paper, but what are the basic facts? The industries that are envisaged - flour milling, textile weaving, steel milling and a host of other manufacturing projects - will no doubt provide employment to many. But, Sir, having produced such goods, the job is to sell them. Unless we can produce cheaply and sell competitively I see no hope for an industrialised Singapore, however hard Government may try to induce investors to set up industries. We are not the only country in Asia which is thinking in terms of industrialisation. And we are not in the fortunate position which some of these countries are in, where they have a huge local population who can easily consume the products that their industries produce without bothering about exports. As I see it, Sir, Government's industrialisation policy, among other things, faces two uncompromising barriers. The first is the lack of a ready and large enough home market to act as a cushion and to make industry worthwhile; and, secondly, the tariff barriers that have been and will ultimately be put up by other producing countries, as has already happened in Indonesia and only a few days ago in the Federation of Malaya. Both these two countries which are our logical buyers and consumers have their own Five-Year Plans and industrial policies; hence we cannot place any confidence in these markets. On the other hand, Sir, we cannot hope to follow the lead taken by Hongkong, where primarily because of its very, very cheap labour it has been able to capture some of the world's markets. It is obvious, therefore, that by the time our industries go into

Column: 93

full gear most of the possible markets now available to us will have already been taken up by the local industries in the territories concerned, or will have been checked one way or another by tariff barriers. Sir, I do not dare to predict that Government's industrial plan will end in failure. But I do say this - that so long as our economy is tied in the way it is to the goodwill of our neighbours, the way ahead is indeed bleak and dark. I therefore hope, Sir, that while implementing its industrial plan, Government would at the same time make greater efforts to convince our neighbours, particularly the Federation of Malaya, that they need us as much as we need them. The only way to do this is to put the general political atmosphere in its proper perspective. Our Prime Minister here, Sir, proclaims that his Government is a Leftist Socialist Government. Across the Straits of Johore, we find the Tunku vociferously repeating that his is a Rightist people's government. Whilst, on the one hand, the people of both these territories tend to regard themselves as Malayans, the Government of both territories are poles apart. Somewhere, Sir, there must be a link, a link that would strike the right note and bring about a common understanding of each other's problems. For only then can there be mutual trust and mutual respect, the foundations upon which to build a prosperous Singapore.

    Sir, while we are on the subject of our relations with the Federation, I am somewhat perturbed to note that it is the intention of the Government eventually to have a trade representative in Kuala Lumpur. I wonder whether this is a wise move. If the object is to have closer relations with the Federation in the economic field, then I think it is the wrong way to go about it. Kuala Lumpur is only 200 miles away, a matter of only an hour's flight from Singapore. Nothing would jeopardize the relations between these two countries more than to have a representative in Kuala Lumpur, a fact which would only tend to emphasise the distinction rather than the common interests of both. Sir, I would advise Government to think again on this matter.

Column: 94



3.21 p.m.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, last year we humbly and earnestly warned the Government that their policy of the big knife and the big axe-

    Mr Byrne: The broad axe.

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: - and the broad axe was being carried out too far; that the drastic cut in the variable allowances of Government servants was a hasty and premature step and might prove unnecessary because the threatened deficit might turn out to be a surplus. As usual, Sir, the arguments of the Opposition were met by a barrage of ridicule sneers and laughter. We also warned the Government that the drastic reduction in the spending power of thousands of Government employees to the tune of millions of dollars would have a chain reaction and that there would be repercussions on the economy of the country. Sir, after 14 years, the truth is out. Our forecasts were correct. The year 1959 ended not with a deficit but with a surplus of $9 million, according to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara, and the year 1960 is likely to end with a deficit of $37 million.

    Mr Byrne: A surplus!

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: With a surplus of $37 million. Ordinarily, Sir, surpluses should be welcomed. But these surpluses as a result of drastic under-expenditure and drastic pay cuts have had very adverse effects on the country's economy.
